content:
I am unclear on you situation. If you have a newer PC, you can transfer 100% from the old to the new with these steps:

  1. start thunderbird on old PC
  2. click tools>export and then click 'open profile folder'
  3. exit thunderbird
  4. copy profile content to external media
  5. install thunderbird on new pc, downloaded from thunderbird.net
  6. in receiving PC, click help>troubleshootinginformation
  7. scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'
  8. exit thunderbird
  9. now, paste contents of exported profile, overlaying contents of profile.
  10. if there is a compatibilitie.ini file, delete it
  11. restart thunder

if The old PC was a POP account and you just want to copy some of the messages to a different PC, that is also possible. Please clarify you intent. Thanks
creator: davidsk

content:
Thank you for the detailed explanation. Once I get the new PC set up, I can try that process. Then would the whole Thunderbird open under the transferred profile(s)? Your comment about 'external media' may involve using a thumb drive, not a CD, to export the profile? Why in steps 3 and 8, would I exit Thunderbird before I copy or paste the profile info?

Yes, the old PC is a POP account. Would I do things differently then? There are files like 'family' and specific organizations that have emails saved under them, and I would like to save the whole files if possible. So there is the question: once my profile is open in a new PC, will those files be available in the new profile? Or do I need to download them from the old PC?

Thank you for your help! Susan C.H.
creator: sclarkharris

content: - CD or thunbdrive, whichever works for you. THumbdrives are just simpler. You are to exit thunderbird to ensure that thunderbird has released control of all the files. Otherwise, you might find the copied profile is incomplete. Yes, as I state in step 8, exit thunderbird prior to pasting the new profile. As a visual reminder, what is happening is that, when you step 2 and step 8, you will have both Thunderbird open and Windows File Explorer open. By exiting thunderbird, all you will be left with is file explorer. In going through the steps, it becomes obvious. The profile copes everything, absolutely everything. When you restart on new PC after pasting in the profile, you should see everything there, all folders, all accounts, and the complete addressbook, plus all of your settings.
creator: davidsk

content:
There is a way to force OAuth2 if it doesn't appear in the menu, but I wonder if the issue in your case is tied to using STARTTLS on port 143. That is a standard setting, but as far as I know, Google accounts, certainly the consumer ones, connect on port 993 with SSL/TLS security for IMAP.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1451090#answer-1659631

content:
The correct pref. is mail.server.serverN.authMethod, where N = 1,2,3...

mail.server.serverN.hostname shows the server name.

content:
I think the last 3 entries in your first picture are incorrect. On my setup, the gmail account corresponds to N = 5, and these are two of the preferences:

mail.server.server5.hostname has the value imap.gmail.com

mail.server.server5.authMethod has the value 10 (for OAuth2)

Each of your accounts corresponds to a different N = 1,2,3,...

I also have mail.smtpserver.smtp3.hostname with the value smtp.gmail.com and

mail.smtpserver.smtp3.authMethod with the value 10

Yes, it seems complex, but the vast majority of users don't need to do this. You have to match the accounts with the correct prefs in order to set the authentication method.

Uninstalling and reinstalling the program is unnecessary in this case as the user data (profile) is separate from the program folder.
creator: sfhowes

content: I notice the IMAP server is shown as mail.varding...se Is this the server name required for your workspace account, or the one 'guessed' by the TB account wizard? I believe that workspace accounts use the same servers as consumer accounts, i.e. imap.gmail.com, 993, SSL/TLS, OAuth2; smtp.gmail.com, 465, SSL/TLS, OAuth2. If that's the case with your accounts, there's no need to perform all these pref. changes.

content:
First, although profile names have no specific function, do NOT rename them casually. That is because the thunderbird startup profile expects the same name as the last time. Just leave alone. The best you can do is to not have an unworkable system. Technically, you could rename the profile 'charlie' or 'suzie' and it would work just the same. but thunderbird has to know that's the name before it starts.

YES, thunderbird uses just one profile. you can safely delete all others from the ...appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles folder. I did that, as it was just wasted space.
creator: davidsk

content:
I'm not clear about what your intent is. If you want to extract addresses from all the messages in a local folder and add them to an address book that can then be exported to a CSV file, it can be done with the aid of the alternative address book, "Cardbook".

https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/cardbook/

- Create a new local Cardbook address book

- Create a Message Filter for Local Folders like shown in the attached image, where the criteria is "Age is greater than 0 days" (to select all messages in the foler); action is "Add From to Cardbook" (you can also choose To, CC, and BCC addresses).

- Select the local folder in question and run the filter against it.

The receiving Cardbook Address Book will have all addresses, including duplicates, so it may need some grooming. Cardbook includes a de-dupe tool.

I expect there are other ways to do this, and you may not want to install Cardbook for just this operation. Since I already use Cardbook, this is how I'd do it.

If this isn't your goal, please clarify.
creator: rednoise

My AOL account stopped recognising my password and all the mail disappeared. I had to setup a new AOL app specific password, then it redownloaded everything. This happened twice with this account.
